Two years ago, I wrote about an awesome little AI tool that turns children’s drawings into funny animations with a single click.

My children absolutely loved it!

The tool was developed by one of our AI scientists as part of his postdoctoral research, and I’m thrilled to share that today we’re open-sourcing the code + releasing a first-of-its-kind dataset of nearly 180k annotated amateur drawings to help other researchers drive even more innovation in this space.

Drawing is a near-universal way for people around the world to capture characters, scenes, or ideas quickly. Our hope is that open sourcing this work will make it easier for other researchers to explore new tools and techniques where AI can complement human creativity.

If you haven’t tried it yet, I honestly can’t recommend it enough. 👇

Try the tool: http://bit.ly/3UBRDMc
Research paper: http://bit.ly/3mq6Hjj
Code & Dataset: http://bit.ly/407XJoH

Have fun! 😊

I couldn’t be prouder. Today, we can begin to turn millions of Americans’ hopes into reality. We have worked tirelessly to make the impossible possible, steadfast in our belief that science will win.

The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine has not been approved or licensed by the U.S. FDA, but has been authorized for emergency use by FDA, under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) to prevent Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) for use in individuals 16 years of age and older. The emergency use of this product is only authorized for the duration of the declaration that circumstances exist justifying the authorization of emergency use of this product unless the declaration is terminated or authorization revoked sooner. Please see EUA Fact Sheet at www.cvdvaccine.com.

If you are tasked with building your company's growth strategy, bookmark this post and try incorporating these key strategies I’m utilizing as a VP of Growth Marketing at Allied.

1. Think in terms of Growth Levers: 

In the simplest terms, growth marketing can be seen as a function of executing strategies that effect one or both of the following desired outcomes:

1) Get More Submissions
2) Improve Close Rate

My lense for decision making boils down to only investing time and money into activities that will effect these growth levers and drive maximum value. This makes it easy to say no to the laundry list of ideas that might fall on your desk and help you get into a growth-focused mindset.

2. Increase Submissions: 

In order to increase submissions, you need more of your ICP to be interested in your products/services. So how do you do that?

- For me, investment in brand awareness is a must. LinkedIn ads, in all formats and with varied messages, targeted to your ICP is the quickest and most cost effective way to guarantee consistent brand awareness that creates demand.

- Be physically where your clients are- whether that's regional speaking engagements, virtual panel discussions, or yes, even having a booth or table at key conferences. 

- Partnerships and industry collaborations. Tap into captive audiences and cross-sell your product/solution through sponsorships or strategic alliances. 

- And, don't forget about hosting your own events. Carefully curated experiences can pique the interest of high-potential prospects and / or reaffirm current customer’s loyalty.

3. Improve Close Rate: 

Once we have those interested prospects, how do we convert them?

- A well-crafted strategic narrative can truly make a difference here. 

- High-quality, professional sales decks, revamped enablement materials, and direct mail/gifting strategies can significantly boost your conversion rate. 

- Professionally written case studies can also work wonders, giving prospects a tangible example of your product or service's success.


4. In-depth Analysis: 

Dig into data, understand your current submissions, and close rates. Identify where there are gaps and opportunities for growth. 

- Are we winning more frequently within a certain demographic? 

- Are our close rates lower within a particular segment? 

Comprehensive analysis will allow you to focus your initiatives on the areas they're needed most.


5. Embrace Continuous Improvement: 

Growth is an iterative process. Every step we take, we learn, we adapt, and we continue on, a little smarter than before. 

- Be open to new approaches, willing to experiment, and focus on refinement. 

- By committing to a continuous improvement mindset, you'll build credibility and momentum over time.

Remember, growth is not a destination, but a journey. Each step we take, each lever we pull brings us closer to our ultimate goals. 

What other strategies have you used to drive growth? 

Share your insights below 👇

Who can relate?
Tag someone who needs to see this.

#enterpreneurship #businessadvisory  #managementconsulting

It was a true honor to welcome President Biden and his team to Pfizer’s Kalamazoo, Michigan site today. He met and thanked many of our unsung heroes – the essential, frontline workers, who have been working around the clock throughout the pandemic to ensure a continuous supply of critical hospital medicines, and to produce and ship the Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine.
 
Much credit has been given, and rightfully so, to our research and development teams for moving at the speed of science to develop the world’s first COVID-19 vaccine approved in the US and around the world in less than a year. But equally important is the extraordinary innovation and accomplishments of our manufacturing and supply chain colleagues.

But hey, it will be worth it in the end😉

Jadav Payeng's work in planting and nurturing a forest for over four decades can be seen as a powerful example of #leadership. 

Here are a few ways in which Payeng's work demonstrates leadership qualities:

1. Vision: Payeng had a clear vision of what he wanted to achieve - to transform a barren island into a thriving forest. He was able to see the potential of the land and the positive impact it could have on the local environment and wildlife.

2. Perseverance: Payeng's work required a great deal of perseverance. He spent decades planting and nurturing trees, often facing challenges such as floods and animal attacks. Despite these obstacles, he remained committed to his goal and continued to work tirelessly to achieve it.

3. Initiative: Payeng took the initiative to start his work, even though it was not part of any official government or non-profit program. He saw a problem - the lack of trees on the island - and took action to solve it, using his own resources and initiative.

Thoughts?

#inspiration #leadershipdevelopment

Are you a boss or a leader? Do you know the difference?

Being a boss means you're in charge, you make the decisions, and you give orders. It can be effective in some situations, but it can also create a negative work environment and demotivate employees.

Being a leader, on the other hand, means inspiring and motivating your team to achieve a common goal. It involves listening to your team, empowering them, and leading by example. It creates a positive work culture and fosters creativity and innovation.

So, which one is better? Let's start a debate in the comments and see what you think. Are you a boss or a leader? Why? Let's share our experiences and insights and learn from each other.

#leadership #leadershipdevelopment #businessandmanagement

Psst, #demandgen leaders. I’m going to let you in on a secret. 

The phrase “positive signal” is going to become your new best friend.

Especially if you are helping your company make the switch from #leadgeneration to #demandgeneration.

This phrase is going to get you through the early months of building a demand-centric mentality with your stakeholders.

Because effective demand gen takes time. (Link to Blake Strozyk recent post in comments to help drive this point home).

And you will not see results in days, weeks, or yes, even months. 

But you will see positive signals.

And these are the data points that you will want to be hyper focused on sharing early and often as you get your program off the ground. 

Signals like:
- Comments/Likes/Shares from key ICP profiles
- Ad/post engagement rate percentages
- Clicks to your Company Page from ads
- ICP profiles that follow your Company Page
- Time on site from demand create channel visitors
- Pages/session from demand create channel visitors
- 50%+ video watch rate metrics
- Etc.

But today, let’s talk about my favorite positive signal: Brand Awareness Growth, and how I like to present this data when reporting. 

To summarize Tory Kindlick's recent post on this topic (link in comments), Brand Awareness Growth is an aggregated view of branded paid search, branded organic search and direct traffic coming to your website over a period of time.

This metric is a staple in many Refine Labs monthly/quarterly reports because it help our clients make positive correlations between their investment in our strategy while also further supporting their internal change management efforts. 

The image below is my preferred way for sharing this positive signal ever since both Payton Christopher and Myles Madden wowed several clients with this clean, easy to digest chart.

It quickly became my favorite way to visualize this signal because it lead to my two important unlocks: 1) trust in the processes and 2) thought-provoking discussion that helped move programs into new and exciting phases.

Give it a look and let me know what you think!

With August right around the corner, many of us will be working on Monthly Performance Reviews this week. If you add Brand Awareness Growth to your report - leave a comment below and let me know how it was received!

Happy reporting!

#demandgenallison

Skill versus experience is a topic that often sparks debates, but the truth is that both are crucial for success. 

Skills are the foundation upon which you build your experience, and experience is the result of applying your skills in real-life situations.

Having a strong set of skills is essential to excel in any field, but it's not enough on its own.

 Experience teaches you how to use your skills effectively and helps you develop the critical thinking and problem-solving abilities needed to navigate complex situations.

So, the question is not whether one is more important than the other, but rather how to strike the right balance between the two. 

While having skills is a good starting point, it's equally important to put them into practice to gain the necessary experience.

Ultimately, it's the combination of skills and experience that sets you apart and enables you to achieve your goals.

 So, keep learning new skills, and don't be afraid to take on new challenges to gain valuable experience. 

With dedication, perseverance, and a willingness to learn, you can master any skill and gain the experience needed to succeed in any field.

Now, I would love to hear your thoughts. What do you think is more important, skill or experience? 

Share your insights in the comments below, and let's start a conversation about this important topic!

#experience #skills #enterpreneurship

Have you ever considered the impact of tolerating poor performance or toxic behavior in the workplace? 

It's not just a matter of letting bad employees get away with subpar work or negative attitudes. 

In fact, it can have a direct impact on the morale and productivity of your entire team, including your star performers.

Nothing will kill a good employee faster than watching you tolerate a bad one. 

When you fail to address poor performance or toxic behavior, it sends a message that you don't value excellence and don't care about creating a positive work environment. 

Your best employees may start to feel demotivated, disengaged, and resentful that they are putting in extra effort while others get a free pass.

So, the next time you encounter an underperforming or toxic employee, think about the message you're sending to your entire team. 

Are you willing to sacrifice the success and happiness of your top performers for the sake of avoiding a difficult conversation or making a tough decision? 

Or will you take action to protect and nurture the talent that makes your organization thrive?

#work #leadership #businessandmanagement

I’m excited to dive into the world of #demandgeneration reporting with you all.

But in order for us to get started, I actually have to back up first.

Because the key to executing successful reporting is understanding how to organize data to be used in a consistent, effective and scalable way.

Enter the Master Reporting Doc.

For me, this is a Google Sheet comprised of 6 Pillar Tabs:

- Inbound Business Performance
- Inbound Pacing
- Monthly Cohorting Analysis
- Budget Pacing
- Demand Capture Analysis
- Demand Creation Analysis

Additional tabs use API connections to pull in raw data from ad platforms and CRM systems to feed these pillars.

𝘗𝘳𝘰 𝘵𝘪𝘱: 𝘍𝘰𝘤𝘶𝘴 𝘰𝘯 𝘴𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘶𝘱 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘐𝘯𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘥 𝘉𝘶𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘦𝘴𝘴 𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘣 𝘧𝘪𝘳𝘴𝘵.

The metrics housed in this tab allow me to create 𝟯𝟬+ 𝘃𝗶𝘀𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘇𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 to help analyze and share business performance related to investment in demand generation.

To get started, in the first column, list out your time periods. Create a section for MoM and QoQ. I typically limit my data set to the current and previous fiscal year.

Then, in the first row, list all of the different metrics you want to track. I use over 40! 𝘚𝘦𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘧𝘶𝘭𝘭 𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘵!

A few things to remember when you are building the reports that feed these metrics:

1) You should be measuring Inbound holistically. Do not limit your reporting analysis to paid channels only. Include data for leads, opportunities and deals that are generated from high-intent form submissions commonly attributed to Direct, Organic, Paid Search, Paid Social and Organic Social channels.

2) Include multiple date field properties so you can report in both cohorted and un-cohorted views. At a minimum you will want to include: Form Submission Date, Demo Scheduled Date, Demo Completed Date, Opportunity Create Date and Close Date.

3) Include fields that allow you to calculate Pipeline Velocity: Total Opps Created, Total Closed Deals, Total Closed-Lost Deals, Total Closed-Won Deals, Days to Close, Total ARR.

And that’s how you can begin setting up the data collection for your Business Performance Tab!

Later this week I plan to show and analyze different charts we can create with this data. I’ll also show a preview of what this sheet actually looks like and how I do some of the calculations over on TikTok!

Questions? Drop them below!

#demandgeneration #demandgenallison

Such a smart initiative!

Wells on wheels launches its water wheel to raise attendance of young girls in schools in India.

Designed with the needs of young girls in mind, the Water Wheel is a sturdy, lightweight and easy-to-use device that allows them to transport large quantities of water with minimal effort.

Its unique shape and size enable it to navigate even the narrowest and most uneven paths, making it the perfect tool for fetching water in rural areas.

#india #inspiration #innovation

Did you know that only 8% of the 500 companies in the S&P 500 have a female CEO, but that they've outperformed the 92% male-led companies over the past 10 years? 🔥 

Over the last 10 years, the difference in returns is clear: 
▶ 384% from female-led companies vs. 
▶ 261% from male-led companies. 

A few notable companies with women CEOs are General Motors, UPS, Citi, and CVS Health 👏 

Often when I talk to entrepreneurs, investors or people in the community, people ask the question, "Do you have any data to back up your thesis that female founders can/do perform better?"

The chart below is one of them + there's a lot more.

What we learn from charts like the below is:
🔶  8% (41) of the 500 companies in the S&P 500 are women-led ♀ 
This number itself is shocking, just like all the other statistics, showing that women are underrepresented in Boards, Management layers and generally among founders

Not all of the 41 companies have had a woman as CEO for all of the last 10 years, but the main point is that the type of company that would appoint a woman as CEO is more likely to have been forward-thinking even before bringing her on. 

However, if you compared the 41 companies to the actual period where women-led companies had a female CEO, the women-led companies still outperform the male-led companies + the market as well.

🔶 92% (459) of the 500 companies in the S&P 500 are male-led ♂ 
Men are overrepresented and if you believe this chart + a lot of research done on women-led vs. male-led companies, it's clear investors/shareholders could be losing out not having more companies be women-led

A lot of VC's are opening their eyes to the fact that we need to invest more in women and I'm particularly proud that we at BackingMinds have been strong believers in this thesis for 7 years. 

💡 In regards to the future:
1) We hope to see more VC's drive this change in the early stage of the company lifecycle
2) We hope more companies/startups will address their gender imbalance in the near future
3) We hope more companies/startups address all forms of diversity at the highest levels of leadership - gender, ethnicity, age, backgrounds etc.
4) We hope to see more women go for leadership roles

The change needs to be accelerated. 

Source of chart + data: Jeremy Schneider / Personal Finance Club 🔥 

CC: Sara Susanne Sara Elsa Sophia Mattias 

#womenled #womenleaders #femaleled #femaleleaders #diversity #venturecapital #diversityandinclusion
